cut.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to reduce the amount of something
cut.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: They’re introducing CCTV cameras in an attempt to cut street crime in the area.
You need to cut the amount of fat and sugar in your diet.
Scientists are warning that unless carbon emissions are cut, we could be heading for an environmental catastrophe.
Seven hundred jobs will be lost in order to cut costs and boost profits.
The major aviation companies need to cut prices if they are to compete with budget airlines.
Staffing levels had already been cut to the bone (=reduced to the lowest level possible).
The welfare budget has been cut by $56 billion.
cut something by £1 million/$5 billion/half etc
A new direct service will cut two hours off the flying time between London and Seoul.
cut.translation[0].definitions[1].signpo: divide something with a knife, scissors etc
cut.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to divide something or separate something from its main part, using scissors, a knife etc
cut.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: Do you want me to cut the cake?
The telephone wires had been cut minutes before the assault.
Cut the carrots into thin strips.
The curtain pole can be cut to length.
Jane cut the cord with a knife.
Can you cut me a piece of bread, please?
Using a pair of scissors, cut carefully along the dotted lines.
We’ll need a saw that will cut through metal.
cut.translation[0].definitions[2].signpo: make something shorter with a knife etc
cut.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to make something shorter with a knife, scissors etc, especially in order to make it neater
cut.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: For reasons of hygiene, we had to cut our fingernails really short.
From outside came the sound of someone cutting the hedge.
It’s about time you got your hair cut.
cut.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: to remove parts from a film, book, speech etc, for example because it is too long or might offend people
cut.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: The original version was cut by more than 30 minutes.
cut.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: to make a hole or mark in the surface of something, or to open it using a sharp tool
cut.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: Cut a hole in the middle of the paper.
Cut open the chillies and remove the seeds.
The blade cut deep into the wood.
Strange letters had been cut into the stone.
cut.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: to injure yourself on something sharp that breaks the skin and makes you bleed
cut.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: She fell and cut her head open.
I noticed he’d cut his finger quite badly.
Marcie said she’d cut herself on a broken glass.
That knife’s extremely sharp! Mind you don’t cut yourself.
On Eric’s chin was a scrap of cotton wool where he’d cut himself shaving.
cut.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: to make or form something from a solid piece of wood, metal etc using a sharp tool
cut.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: I’ll get a spare key cut for you.
The chair had been cut from the trunk of a tree.
cut.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: to cut something such as metal or rope in order to let someone escape from where they are trapped
cut.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: He was in the vehicle for an hour before he was cut free.
She had to be cut from the wreckage of her car.
cut.translation[0].definitions[8].defini: if a tool cuts well, badly etc, it cuts things well or badly etc
cut.translation[0].definitions[8].exampl: professional quality tools that cut efficiently and smoothly
cut.translation[0].definitions[9].defini: if a piece of clothing is cut in a particular way, that is the way it is designed and made
cut.translation[0].definitions[9].exampl: The T-shirt is cut fairly low at the neck.
cut.translation[0].definitions[9].note_b: Cut is usually passive in this meaning
cut.translation[0].definitions[10].defin: to remove something from a document or file on a computer
cut.translation[0].definitions[10].examp: To cut text, press Control + C.
Cut and paste the picture into a new file  (=remove it and then make it appear in a new file).
cut.translation[0].definitions[11].defin: to get to somewhere by a quicker and more direct way than the usual way
cut.translation[0].definitions[11].examp: I usually cut through the car park to get to work.
cut.translation[0].definitions[12].defin: to divide an area into two or more parts
cut.translation[0].definitions[12].examp: The river cuts the whole region in two.
The new road will cut through a conservation area.
cut.translation[0].definitions[13].defin: to divide a pack of cards into two
cut.translation[0].definitions[13].examp: First cut the pack, and then deal the cards
cut.translation[0].definitions[14].defin: to produce a CD, song etc for people to buy
cut.translation[0].definitions[14].examp: The band cut their first single in 2001.
cut.translation[0].definitions[15].defin: to take the top part off crops such as wheat before gathering them
cut.translation[0].definitions[16].defin: to put the parts of a film together so that they make a continuous story, and get rid of the parts you do not want
cut.translation[0].definitions[17].defin: in a film, if the camera cuts away or cuts to a different scene, the scene on the screen changes to a different one
cut.translation[0].definitions[17].examp: At the crucial moment, the camera cuts away and we don't see the murder.
The shark is shown moving through the water and then we cut to a shot of the beach.
cut.translation[0].definitions[18].defin: if a line cuts another line, they cross each other at a particular point
cut.translation[0].definitions[19].defin: if a baby cuts a tooth, the tooth starts to grow
cut.translation[0].definitions[20].defin: to mix an illegal drug such as heroin with another substance
cut.translation[0].definitions[20].note_: Cut is often passive in this meaning
cut.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: to reduce the amount of something
cut.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: They cut costs by getting rid of staff.
Shops have been forced to cut their prices after very slow sales.
The government is expected to cut interest rates next month.
In the 1990s, governments worldwide cut military spending.
The bank announced that it was cutting 500 jobs.
Cameras have helped to cut crime in the town centre.
Housing benefit was sharply cut for all but the poorest people.
Funding for art and music in schools has been cut to the bone.
cut.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 2: to divide something or separate something from its main part, using scissors, a knife etc
cut.translation[0].note_box[1].sections[: cut somebody a piece/slice of something
Shall I cut you a slice of cake?
Next cut the carrots into thin slices.
The place where I bought the wood cut it to size for me.
Cut open the avocado and remove the stone.
First cut the fish in half lengthways.
Branches should be cut cleanly from the tree.
cut.translation[0].note_box[2].sections[: to divide something into two or more pieces, especially using a knife or scissors
Do you want me to cut the cake?
He cut off the lower branches.
snip
to quickly cut something, especially using scissors
I snipped the label off.
The hairdresser snipped away at her hair.
slit
to make a long narrow cut through something, especially using a knife
He slit the envelope open with a penknife.
She slit through the plastic covering.
slash
to cut something quickly and violently with a knife, making a long thin cut
Someone had slashed the tyres on his car.
He tried to slash his wrists.
saw
to cut wood, using a saw (=a tool with a row of sharp points)
Saw the wood to the correct length.
chop
to cut wood, vegetables, or meat into pieces
Bill was outside chopping up firewood with an axe.
They chopped down the old tree.
finely chopped onion
slice
to cut bread, meat, or vegetables into thin pieces
I’ll slice the cucumber.
Slice the bread thinly.
dice
to cut vegetables or meat into small square pieces
First dice the apple into cubes.
grate
to cut cheese or a hard vegetable by rubbing it against a special tool
Grate the cheese and sprinkle it over the vegetables.
peel
to cut the outside part off something such as a potato or apple
I peeled the potatoes and put them in a saucepan.
carve
to cut thin pieces from a large piece of meat
Uncle Ray carved the turkey.
mow
to cut the grass in a garden, park etc
A gardener was mowing the lawn.
trim
to cut a small amount off something, especially to make it look neater
He was trimming his beard.
Trim the excess fat off the meat.
cut.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: said by the director of a film to tell people to stop acting, filming etc
cut.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: a reduction in the size or amount of something, especially the amount of money that is spent by a government or company
cut.translation[2].definitions[0].exampl: There will be cuts across all levels of the company.
The decision to make cuts in health care provision has been widely criticized.
The building plans could be hit by possible spending cuts.
A shorter working week will mean pay cuts for millions of workers.
Cuts in public spending mean that fewer people can go on to higher education.
A cut of 1% in interest rates was announced yesterday.
cut.translation[2].definitions[1].defini: a wound that is caused when something sharp cuts your skin
cut.translation[2].definitions[1].exampl: That’s quite a nasty cut – you ought to get it seen to by a doctor.
The driver escaped with minor cuts and bruises.
cut.translation[2].definitions[2].defini: a narrow hole or mark in the surface of something, made by a sharp tool or object
cut.translation[2].definitions[2].exampl: Make a small cut in the paper.
cut.translation[2].definitions[3].defini: an act of cutting someone’s hair
cut.translation[2].definitions[3].exampl: How much do they charge for a cut and blow-dry?
cut.translation[2].definitions[4].defini: the style in which your hair is cut
cut.translation[2].definitions[5].defini: the style in which clothes have been made
cut.translation[2].definitions[5].exampl: I could tell by the cut of his suit that he wasn’t a poor man.
cut.translation[2].definitions[6].defini: someone’s share of something, especially money
cut.translation[2].definitions[6].exampl: She was determined to claim her cut of the winnings.
cut.translation[2].definitions[7].defini: an act of removing a part from a film, play, piece of writing etc, or a part that has been removed
cut.translation[2].definitions[8].defini: the process of putting together the different parts of a film and removing the parts that will not be shown
cut.translation[2].definitions[8].exampl: Spielberg himself oversaw the final cut.
cut.translation[2].definitions[9].defini: one of the songs or pieces of music on an album, CD etc
cut.translation[2].definitions[10].defin: a piece of meat that has been cut to a size suitable for cooking or eating
cut.translation[2].definitions[10].examp: Long slow cooking is more suitable for cheaper cuts of meat.
cut.translation[2].definitions[11].defin: a road that has been made through a hill
cut.translation[2].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: a reduction in the size or amount of something, especially the amount of money that is spent by a government or company
cut.translation[2].note_box[0].sections[: The country needs to make cuts in the carbon dioxide it produces.
A major engineering company has announced big job cuts.
Some employees were forced to take pay cuts.
Millions of workers face pay cuts.
There have been falling sales and job cuts at the newspaper.
His proposals could involve spending cuts of up to £12 billion.
The company announced big price cuts on all its computers.
Further proposals for defence cuts were drawn up.
Deep cuts were made in research spending.
He resigned over drastic cuts in the education budget.
cut.translation[2].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 2: a wound that is caused when something sharp cuts your skin
cut.translation[2].note_box[1].sections[: He had a cut on his forehead.
I fell and got a bad cut on my head.
Two passengers had to be treated for minor cuts.
I’m fine - just a few superficial cuts.
How did you get that nasty cut?
She fell and got a deep cut on her leg.
He escaped the crash with just a few cuts and bruises.
cut.translation[3].definitions[0].defini: a planned reduction in the amount or level of something
cut.translation[3].definitions[0].exampl: the president’s programme of budget cuts
Though it announced price cuts in June, its PCs still sell for more than those of its foreign competitors.
The chairman took an $800,000 cut in pay last year because of poor profits.
cut.translation[3].definitions[1].defini: the share of an amount of money that someone is allowed to take for themselves, especially as a reward or payment for helping someone to earn the total amount
cut.translation[3].definitions[1].exampl: The video has been hugely popular, yet Jones received only £1,600 after his agents took their cut.
cut.translation[4].definitions[0].defini: to reduce prices, amounts, money etc
cut.translation[4].definitions[0].exampl: She criticized supermarkets for failing to pass on profits to customers by cutting prices.
There’s always pressure on the organisation to increase productivity and cut costs.
Unfortunately, we need to cut our workforce by a third.
